Award.AwardTitle: Understanding multistep electron transfer reactions for the design of photsensory proteins

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
In biological systems, many metabolic processes involve electron transfer (ET) reactions, which function to direct the movement of electrons among macromolecules without dissipating the high free energy needed to drive chemical transformations. ET is often multi-step in that reactive protein residues act as waystations to harbor electrons or their vacancies ('holes') during long-range charge migration. Understanding this so-called electron, or hole, 'hopping' is important for adapting key properties of proteins for the purpose of energy conversion. This project will apply spectroscopic and structural techniques to study the role of multi-step ET in model systems and in native biological light sensors to test mechanisms and design new functionality. These studies also will have important prospects for optogenetics, the development and use of engineered photosensitive proteins for controlling cellular processes, including circadian rhythms, with light. The project will involve graduate and undergraduate students in cutting edge research in fields including enzymology, protein biochemistry, structural biology, spectroscopy, chemical kinetics, and protein engineering. The collaborative and multidisciplinary nature of the project will expose students to research that bridges disciplines and scientific cultures. The project will also couple to an on-going program developed by the PI to engage students from under-represented groups in scientific research.

This project aims to understand multi-step ET reactions that involve reactive protein side chains (i.e., hopping) in photoactive proteins. Kinetic and structural studies of a photosensitive model system composed of redox partners cytochrome c peroxidase and cytochrome c will explore the reactivity of a Tryptophan/Tyrosine hopping center by systematic perturbation of the radical environment and incorporation of non-natural amino acids at the hopping site. Coupled work on hole-hopping in blue-light sensing cryptochromes and Light- Oxygen- Voltage (LOV) photoreceptors will probe the biophysical attributes that allow reactive protein side chains to mediate rapid and stable charge separation in these flavin-containing photosensors. For a new class of LOV-like protein, multi-step ET involving non-aromatic residues will be investigated. Redesign of these systems will test hypotheses, confirm mechanisms and develop tools for applications of optogenetics, the field of engineering cellular systems to be regulated by light.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electron transfer (ET) reactions underlie much of energy transduction and metabolism. Biological systems are well adapted to direct the movement of electrons among macromolecules without dissipating the high free energy needed to drive chemical transformations. ET is often multistep in that reactive protein residues act as way stations to harbor electrons or their vacancies (“holes”) during long-range charge migration. Understanding such so-called electron or hole “hopping” is important for adopting key properties of proteins for the purpose of energy conversion. Moreover, it has recently become apparent that biological light sensing employs multistep ET in processes that convert photon energy into changes in protein conformation. Hopping reactions effectively maintain separation between electrons and holes in a manner important for signal processing, energy harvesting strategies, and the production of interacting pairs of distant electrons, which have been implicated in biological sensing of Earth’s magnetic field.  This project applied spectroscopic and structural techniques to study the role of multi-step ET in both model systems and native biological light sensors. In the CcP system we established a model amenable to unnatural amino acid incorporation and capable of studying proton-coupled electron transfer in a controlled manner. We experimentally demonstrated the important principle that the redox potential of Tyrosine must be low enough to undergo oxidation, but the resulting deprotonated radical must retain a high enough potential to act as an effective hopping site. The dynamics of the protic environment are critical to appropriately modulate this reactivity Furthermore, we reveal the unappreciated role of methionine residues in long-range protein electron transfer. In LOV proteins we discovered the high degree of redundancy in the internal electron sources within the protein, yet a high degree of specificity in controlling coupled proton transfers to the reactive cofactor. We have also revealed the potential of photoactive LOV-like proteins to act as new in vivo probes for protein associations and conformational changes. In the case of cryptochrome we are progressing toward new tools that have important prospects for optogenetics, the development and use of engineered photosensitive proteins for controlling cellular processes with light. The modulation of electron and proton flow in light sensors will enable responses to light of different colors in neurobiological investigations of circadian rhythms.

The study of biological electron transfer is important for not only understanding the underlying parameters of catabolic and anabolic reactions, but increasingly more so, the regulation of these processes and protection against oxidative damage.  In addition, biomimicry of effective energy transduction processes for energy generation and storage relies on reproducing parameters that biology optimizes well, such as high absorption cross-sections for light absorption, high quantum yields for charge separation, limited recombination reactions and maintenance of chemical potential throughout the charge transfer process.  It has been long recognized that the judicious placement of redox active cofactors mediates long-range charge transfer in biological energy transduction. Furthermore, the role of redox active protein residues in these reactions has received increasing prominence. In particular, protein residues that have redox potentials in range of high-valent or excited-state accepter sites have been shown to mediate ET in systems such as photosystem II, cytochrome oxidase, ribonucleotide reductase, galactose oxidase, lipoxygenase, cytochrome c peroxidase, and photolyases.  In addition, redox active aromatic residues are important for light-sensing processes, such as those mediated by the three major classes of blue-light sensitive photoreceptors: cryptochromes, LOV proteins and BLUF proteins. Thus, long-range charge transfer and stabilizing charge separation are central issues in many fields within biology, and those beyond, including solar energy production and battery development. Our results demonstrate that in well characterized, but complex molecular systems, that the spatial control of protonation, placement of redox active groups and maintenance of redox potential at relay sites have profound effects on ET reactivity and the ability of light to drive functionally relevant redox-active processes. We have applied the principles learned toward developing new biological photosensors that can be used as tools in cellular experiments; however, our results should be directly applicable to any system where control of ET is desirable for increased performance.  

The PI devoted considerable effort to the training of persons historically excluded because of ethnicity or race (PEERs) and community outreach. The PI initiated and oversees a multi-stage scholastic program at Cornell (CHAMPS) that aims to increase participation of PEER undergraduate students in science and medicine. To date nearly 100 PEER students have benefitted from CHAMPS. CHAMPS is a multi-year program that has components of mentored learning, professional development and research experience. The NSF support enabled late-stage CHAMPS students to participate in high-level independent research and thereby expand engagement of the program throughout the four undergraduate years for some students. Additional scientific outreach efforts have included high school science teacher education, high school student research experience, pre-kindergarten and elementary classroom outreach and participation in Expand Your Horizons activities to encourage young women in science.
